key_points: Byron Leftwich, the Buccaneers' Offensive Coordinator, emphasized the importance of a game plan to exploit the opposing team's weaknesses.
The Buccaneers' game plan against the Kansas City Chiefs in Super Bowl LV focused on play-action fakes and quick throws by Tom Brady.
This strategy led to a 31-9 victory for the Buccaneers, securing their second championship in franchise history.
Tom Brady utilized play-action on 43% of his dropbacks during the game, the highest in his career according to NFL Next Gen Stats.
In the first quarter, the Buccaneers ran or faked a handoff on 73% of their plays, reflecting a strategic emphasis on 'run action'.
Brady's execution of the play-action plan resulted in three touchdown passes and a near-perfect passer rating of 149.0.
Brady's targeted receivers had an average of 4.0 yards of separation, the best in any game during the season.
Rob Gronkowski's second touchdown demonstrated both his remaining speed and successful improvisation with Brady.
Brady's quick release time of 2.27 seconds on average helped neutralize the Chiefs' pass rush.
Brady's average time to throw in the first half was the lowest since NFL Next Gen Stats began tracking in 2016.
spokespersons: Byron Leftwich (Offensive Coordinator, Tampa Bay Buccaneers)
